data.name: richTextMain.Text
data.value:
Quadrant Analysis
Background:
Quadrant Analysis views the cyclist as a power source, assuming that factors such as hills, wind, road surface, tactics, your weight, and the bike’s weight are given and fixed, and therefore don’t form part of the analysis: The role of the athlete in this strategy is to maximise the power produced across the activity.
At each point in time the athlete needs to maximise power, while reducing to a minimum the strain, and ultimately fatigue this creates, such that the athlete will be in a position to continue to produce peak output across the full activity.
Quadrant Analysis will assist you to determine if you are consistently producing optimum power, at the lowest possible cost, and will indicate where you may concentrate improvements toward reaching this objective.
Quadrant Analysis in Perspective:
Quadrant Analysis is a valuable view of your performance, that gives a direct indication on where to focus your training efforts in a way that will effect real performance improvements.
Of course Quadrant Analysis is a single perspective, and should not be used as the ONLY analysis tool, but rather as a part of a suite of analysis tools to understand your current position and optimum focus.
The nature of Quadrant Analysis means that the information is viewed after the activity is complete, and indications of the required direction is not available while riding. This means that we have to translate our conclusions to tangible objectives, measurable while riding: Cadence, Power, and Heart Rate.
Data Requirements:
Quadrant Analysis requires:
1. Measured Power: Ideally this should be directly measured using an accurate power meter (PowerTap, SRM, Quark, or other). Indirect measurements (eg iBike) are acceptable, while derived measurements (eg GPSPowerTrack) are likely to compromise the results to some extent. Lacking a power measurement Quadrant Analysis isn’t possible.
2. Cadence: This needs to be a direct, accurate measurement, typically with a crank magnet. Derived measurements (eg Saris) are acceptable with limited compromise.
3. Crank length: A fixed parameter applicable to the bike in use: Used to correctly scale the data.
Note: It’s important that Power and Cadence measurements are accurately time synchronised, and therefore recorded using a common device.
Quadrant Analysis does not require, or benefit from a GPS track, speed, heart rate, heart rate variation, elevation, barometric pressure, environmental factors (wind, temperature, humidity), gear, or other data that might be available.
